biogHists.text:
Administrative History

In 1982 Jane Muramoto produced for public broadcasting television station KQED in San Francisco, a half-hour documentary film of Kenneth Patchen's California years.

Kenneth Patchen: Hurrah for Anything, conveys the personal and human side of Patchen's creativity as told by Miriam Patchen, poet Al Young, small press printer Jonathan Clark, poet and playwright James Schevill, and UCSC Special Collections librarian, Rita Bottoms. The documentary also draws upon existing recordings of Kenneth Patchen reading with jazz ensembles and a 1959 Pacifica network radio interview.

Film is a production of KQED's Events and Presentations Unit. Producers/Directions: Jane Muramoto and Allen Willis. Executive Producers; Jim Scalem and Nat Katzman.

From the guide to the "Kenneth Patchen: Hurrah for Anything" film production records, 1982, (University of California, Santa Cruz. University Library. Special Collections and Archives)

                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>John Paterson correspondence : Berkeley, Calif., 1961-1962.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Correspondence related to his role as host of the television show "Books and Authors" that aired on KQED San Francisco, California. Letter topics include responses to appearance requests, program content, funding, and commentary. Also includes a pencil sketch drawing of Paterson by Al Woo. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>University of California, Berkeley</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Furthering the public welfare, 1929-1991 : oral history transcript / Madeline H. Russell. Interviews conducted by Gabrielle Morris in 1989 and 1991 ; with additional remarks by Susan Silk. Regional Oral History Office, The Bancroft Library, University of California, 1995.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Russell discusses her San Francisco family and childhood and early life; starting the Columbia Foundation, 1939-1940; work on political and philanthropic committees; grantmaking; work with KQED public television; and work with the Democratic party in the 1970s. Also includes a conversation with Susan Silk, Columbia Foundation executive director. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>University of California, Berkeley</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

resource.abstract: Russell discusses her San Francisco family and childhood and early life; starting the Columbia Foundation, 1939-1940; work on political and philanthropic committees; grantmaking; work with KQED public television; and work with the Democratic party in the 1970s. Also includes a conversation with Susan Silk, Columbia Foundation executive director.

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <did xmlns="urn:isbn:1-931666-22-9">
                  <repository>
                     <corpname>Mass Media and Culture</corpname>
                     <address>
                        <addressline>Special Collections, University of Maryland Libraries, Hornbake Library, College Park, MD 20742. Tel: 301-405-9212, Fax: 301-314-2709, Email: askhornbake@umd.edu</addressline>
                     </address>
                  </repository>
                  <origination>
                     <persname>Day, James</persname>
                  </origination>
                  <unittitle>James Day Papers</unittitle>
                  <unitdate>1952-1996 and undated</unitdate>
                  <unitdate>1969-1992</unitdate>
                  <physdesc>21.00 linear feet, including 26 audiovisual items</physdesc>
                  <unitid>NPBA 91-205</unitid>
                  <physloc>Room 3210 (Showcase Room):70:I:Room 3210 (Showcase Room) 71 : A : </physloc>
                  <abstract>From 1953 to 1969, James Day served as the president and general manager of KQED (San Francisco, CA).  For fourteen years, he hosted his own weekly program, <title>Kaleidoscope</title>, on which he interviewed many notable people including Eleanor Roosevelt, Robert Kennedy, and Buster Keaton.  In 1969, Day became president of National Educational Television (NET).  When NET merged with New York's public television channel, WNDT, in 1970 to become WNET/Channel 13, Day became the president of the merged organizations.   In 1973, Day resigned as president of WNET due to his dissatisfaction with public television and the growing importance of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting (CPB) and the Public Broadcasting Service (PBS). He founded his own production company, Publivision, Inc., which produced and syndicated to public stations all over the world a night interview program, <title>Day At Night</title>.  The collection documents Day's career at KQED, NET, WNET, and as an independent consultant in the field of public television. A great deal of the collection consists of Day's research for his 1995 history of public television, <title>The Vanishing Vision: The Inside Story of Public Television</title>.</abstract>
                  <abstract>From 1953 to 1969, James Day served as the president and general manager of KQED (San Francisco, CA).  For fourteen years, he hosted his own weekly program, <title>Kaleidoscope</title>, on which he interviewed many notable people including Eleanor Roosevelt, Robert Kennedy, and Buster Keaton. He founded his own production company, Publivision, Inc., which produced and syndicated to public stations all over the world a night interview program, <title>Day At Night</title>.  The collection documents Day's career at KQED, NET, WNET, and as an independent consultant in the field of public television. A great deal of the collection consists of Day's research for his 1995 history of public television, <title>The Vanishing Vision: The Inside Story of Public Television</title>.</abstract>

He founded his own production company, Publivision, Inc., which produced and syndicated to public stations all over the world a night interview program, <title>Day At Night</title>.  The collection documents Day's career at KQED, NET, WNET, and as an independent consultant in the field of public television. A great deal of the collection consists of Day's research for his 1995 history of public television, <title>The Vanishing Vision: The Inside Story of Public Television</title>.</abstract>
                  <abstract>From 1953 to 1969, James Day served as the president and general manager of KQED (San Francisco, CA).  For fourteen years, he hosted his own weekly program, <title>Kaleidoscope</title>, on which he interviewed many notable people including Eleanor Roosevelt, Robert Kennedy, and Buster Keaton.  In 1969, Day became president of National Educational Television (NET).  When NET merged with New York's public television channel, WNDT, in 1970 to become WNET/Channel 13, Day became the president of the merged organizations.   In 1973, Day resigned as president of WNET due to his dissatisfaction with public television and the growing importance of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting (CPB) and the Public Broadcasting Service (PBS). He founded his own production company, Publivision, Inc., which produced and syndicated to public stations all over the world a night interview program, <title>Day At Night</title>.  The collection documents Day's career at KQED, NET, WNET, and as an independent consultant in the field of public television. A great deal of the collection consists of Day's research for his 1995 history of public television, <title>The Vanishing Vision: The Inside Story of Public Television</title>.</abstract>
               </did>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: James Day Papers 1952-1996 and undated 1969-1992

In 1969, Day became president of National Educational Television (NET).  When NET merged with New York's public television channel, WNDT, in 1970 to become WNET/Channel 13, Day became the president of the merged organizations.   In 1973, Day resigned as president of WNET due to his dissatisfaction with public television and the growing importance of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting (CPB) and the Public Broadcasting Service (PBS). He founded his own production company, Publivision, Inc., which produced and syndicated to public stations all over the world a night interview program, .  The collection documents Day's career at KQED, NET, WNET, and as an independent consultant in the field of public television. A great deal of the collection consists of Day's research for his 1995 history of public television, . resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <did xmlns="urn:isbn:1-931666-22-9">
                  <unittitle>Working Group records</unittitle>
                  <unitdate>1984-2005  </unitdate>
                  <unitdate>(Bulk 1988-1999)</unitdate>
                  <unitid>2008/005, 2009/007</unitid>
                  <origination>
                     <corpname>Working Group Records</corpname>
                  </origination>
                  <physdesc>
                     <extent>33 record cartons.</extent>
                  </physdesc>
                  <repository>
                     <corpname>San Francisco State University. 
<subarea>Labor Archives and Research Center.</subarea>
                     </corpname>
                     <address>
                        <addressline>480 Winston Drive</addressline>
                        <addressline>San Francisco, California 94132</addressline>
                        <addressline>(415) 564-4010</addressline>
                     </address>
                  </repository>
                  <abstract>
The Working Group Collection contains production, research, outreach, and financial records generated by the The Working Group in producing the television series <emph>California Working,</emph>
                     <emph>We Do the Work</emph>, and <emph>Livelyhood.</emph>  The collection also contains materials created in the production of contract documentaries and films for client organizations such as labor unions and apprenticeship programs. The bulk of the collection spans the years 1988-2002, and reveals the activities of the organization in producing local and nationally distributed television programs for broadcast on public television. The Working Group is an independent media production company based in Oakland, California.
</abstract>
                  <physloc>For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Center's online catalog.</physloc>
                  <langmaterial>
Languages represented in the collection: 
<language>English.</language>
                  </langmaterial>
               </did>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Working Group records 1984-2005 (Bulk 1988-1999)
resource.abstract: The Working Group Collection contains production, research, outreach, and financial records generated by the The Working Group in producing the television series , and The collection also contains materials created in the production of contract documentaries and films for client organizations such as labor unions and apprenticeship programs. The bulk of the collection spans the years 1988-2002, and reveals the activities of the organization in producing local and nationally distributed television programs for broadcast on public television. The Working Group is an independent media production company based in Oakland, California. California Working, We Do the Work Livelyhood.
